top_comment.text:
i wonder what Ethiopia would have been like today if the Ethiopian 
leadership did what Japan did in the mid 19th century and invested heavily 
in the development of industry. it could have changed its economy from 
being based on agriculture to being primarily industrial, and the huge 
droughts that hit the country in the 70's wouldn't have caused an economic 
collapse.﻿

I think we like to overplay and stereotype things. Such as Africa is all

top_comment.author: Ashley Meijer

comments.text:
+Victor Ware Which is why I said on average. Misogyny and homophobia at 
least are big problems in parts of Africa. Some countries there have life 
imprisonment for homosexuality. Every country has people who are living 
well, but there are far less of them per capita in most African countries 
compared to the US and Western Europe. We need to recognize that there is a 
problem there in order to fix it. It is improving, but that does not mean 
it is fixed.

P.S. has anyone noticed that right click spell check on YouTube comments 
has been a bit weird lately? It seems to like to leave the first and last 
letters of what you typed there and put the fixed version between them.

comments.text:

top_comment.text:
Fascinating. I love hearing stories like this.  Now I'm wondering if 
whether or not Ethiopia's burgeoning middle class can be attributed to the 
country never having been colonized by Europeans. ﻿
top_comment.author: Timothy Hanrahan

comments.text:
I am not sure that it has anything to do with Ethiopia being free from 
colonization. Africa in general has seen a growing number of middle class 
people over the past decade or so.  And about seven of the ten fastest 
growing economies in the world for the past ten years have been African. 
Countries with rising middle class include Kenya, Ghana, Rwanda, 
Mozambique, Botswana, and so on. And these are all countries that have been 
colonized.
comments.author: Rahel

comments.text: In some ways yes.
comments.author: IIsaezanaII 1st

top_comment.text:
I'll probably get hate for this... Ethiopia actually has similar education 
to Ireland as we gave them School books, stationary etc.. So they'll have 
the Junior and leaving cert, which are state exams in Ireland. So yh, i had 
to say that... ﻿
top_comment.author: Luigi Mario

comments.text: +yichalal amnalew I'm more than happy to hear that! :D
comments.author: Luigi Mario

comments.text:

that. It's all about time, our country is now improving a lot & the Irish 
people generosity will not be forgotten.
comments.author: yichalal amnalew

top_comment.text:
I find it a bit odd that university students talk about the ability to 
integrate. Integral mathematics are just something you learn in high school 
when you're 15 or 16, though perhaps I'm judging by slightly higher 
standards than you should reasonably be able to expect in Ethiopia. 
Assuming she means the kind of integrals with one variable, of course. You 
don't get the full deal of calculus in high school, just the basics. ﻿
top_comment.author: Marco Onyxheart

comments.text:
I find it odd you actually typed that condescending crap and no one (until 
now) has called your corncern trolling tactic out.
comments.author: Victor Ware

comments.text:
Integral calculus was a requirement for graduation at my high school, and 
many finished multivariable by senior year. I'm in California by the way.
comments.author: Anthony Khodanian

comments.text:
+Meseret Wondale That is a WAY better curriculum than my high school in 
Colorado.
comments.author: Raina Ramsay

comments.text:
+Marco Onyxheart Hi, I am Ethiopian and in the old curriculum, Calculus 
starts at Freshman level in College. But the current one, which is adopted 
before 14 years, Calculus is mandatory in Grade 11 and 12 mathematics. Of 
course the integration at that level is with one variable, where the two 
variable is saved for college :)
comments.author: Meseret Wondale

comments.text:
I was under the impression that the girl didnt find it difficult to 
integrate but the difficulty lay in the fact that her topic of study was so 
specialised that talking about her life to others was impossible. If you 
think about it, what she was saynig isn't just a developing world problem 
but a global problem as most of our professions require us to speak and use 
certain words and phrases that in fact alienate us from people outside our 
sphere of expertise.
comments.author: Zara Harrison

comments.text:
I got friends in Ethiopia, and they tell me how stress full it is having to 
study day and night. Don't under estimate High School education in 
Ethiopia. Most of the time you aren't even allowed to touch a calculator in 
math class until your in 9th or 10th grade high school. While in the US 
it's nothing but calculators since 1st grade math.
comments.author: FsimulatorX

comments.text:
Different countries have different standards of education. For example, I'm 
a first year student at a South African university and we were only 
introduced to integration in the second semester of my maths course. The 
only people who were familiar with it before were the kids who did extra 
advanced math at high school and the international students from Mauritius. 
Then again, South Africa has a terribly low standard of school education 
so...
comments.author: Munira Hoosain

comments.text:
Most of my high school and my college graduated without learning calculus 
*or* statistics. I think algebra was required for graduation, but I'm 
honestly not certain even of that.
comments.author: Raina Ramsay

comments.text:
+Richie Lomas Well, I must admit that I'm not sure if everyone learned them 
where I went to school. You had to pick profiles at some point, and I chose 
the physics profile. People from the society profile did tend to get easier 
math.

I'm really surprised at the notion of statistics being easier. If there is 
one subject in math that I hate, it's statistics. All those squared sigmas 
and product moment correlation coefficients (I'm kinda glad I forgot what 
that word meant). All I remember is that I got a 4 or a 5 out of 10 for 
that part. Oh, the horror. We don't do those at 15 years old, of course, 
but I definitely encountered that stuff in high school.
comments.author: Marco Onyxheart

comments.text:
Really?  In my high school we didn't do integration until junior year 
(16/17), and that was if you were in the faster math lane.  Most people 
didn't take it until senior year (17/18), and even that was optional, if 
you wanted to opt for something easier like statistics (where you might 
technically "use" integration, but you really only learned to punch it into 
the calculator rather than the math behind it, which was even true in the 
AP math).  So you could easily graduate from public school without ever 
learning them.
comments.author: Richie Lomas

comments.text: you are FULL of shit
comments.author: dazebhen1

comments.text:
Yep, in England we don't do integration until 17/18 when we do A-levels, 
but you choose your own subjects then and maths is optional so not everyone 
does it, I didn't
comments.author: Kirsty Little

comments.text:
I'm from england and we didn't do integration until A-level maths at 17 or 
18 years old
comments.author: sarahisaravenclaw

comments.text:
+loverangel1 that's really cool! The area I'm from in the US when the 
schools started requiring kids to learn their letters and numbers before 
entering kindergarten, we were all like "Do what? What the heck is school 
for then?" ^^; so it's great seeing another perspective where it's not 
abnormal at all.
comments.author: Jessi Pirkle

comments.text:
That's kind of judgy. I didn't take calculus in high school, and I live in

comments.author: SunyiSideUp

comments.text:
Every country sets it's own pace and teaching style regarding education and

learning integrals at 13 years old. At 15/16 years old a lot of people take

comments.author: loverangel1

comments.text: No calculus in my HS.  Integrals didn't come up until 2nd semester college.
comments.author: kandkserv

comments.text:
where i'm from it is true that integration is taught in high, but only the 
very final parts of it, like late 12th grade. and those are typically not

comments.author: Will Ferrous

comments.text:
I don't think they knew how to spell Calculus in my high school. They 
certainly didn't teach it. If you wanted to learn something like that, they 
would put you on a bus and take you to the community college in the next 
town over.
comments.author: Jim Davidson

comments.text:
At the high school I attended in Missouri, it was only the top-level 
students that learned *any* calculus or integrals - maybe 20 people out of 
a graduating class of around 250. A lot of students graduated with only 
knowledge of algebra and geometry.

comments.text:
To be honest with you i prefer if the government holds 51% of it and let

comments.text:
"At least if you monopolize something you have to fulfill the demand and 
they are not doing that." 
http://addisfortune.net/articles/4g-nearly-in-addis-abeba/
Selling of shares while the government holding 51% of it? that's may be 
acceptable until there are Ethiopian investors with the capital comes along 
which is not that far way. and the government need to get profits for the 
huge public money it invested in.

"Banks are perfect examples after private banks are allowed......
Beverage industries, hotels are other examples"

At least if you monopolize something you have to fulfill the demand and

top_comment.author: Wout12345

comments.text:
+Victor Ware Hmm, I actually have some things to respond here ... But

comments.author: Wout12345

comments.text:
"Bridge that gap"... you sound like such a jackass especially when you pick

"It may as well be a black guy from Germany..." 
You do realize white people and black people are treated differently

Bottom line, what I said in my original reply still stands. The end;

comments.author: Victor Ware

comments.text:
+Victor Ware Well, I didn't say I need him, I just considered it a valuable 
aspect of his narrative. Let's look at it the other way, if one of us were 
to go to, say, Kenya, and get 4 minutes to "describe the West" to the 
people from that culture, I probably wouldn't even know where to start.  
Having a journalist/vlogger/... who understands the culture of their 
audience, to bridge that gap does help to get the story better across to at 
least some degree. Looking back to it, I have to admit it may be 
far-fetched, but I still believe it to be true on some level.

Also, I never said a white guy from America, I was talking about people who 
understand one of the Western cultures, most notably by living in it. It 
may as well be a black guy from Germany as far as I'm concerned.

On the other hand, I do also recognize the value of first-hand accounts. I 
was just playing the devil's advocate for the most part.
comments.author: Wout12345

comments.text:
+Wout12345 If you need a white guy from America to make a story about 
people different from him (mind you, from a country he's never lived in) 
"relatable" enough for you to listen to said people's lives, you need to 
reevaluate your life. 
Like seriously, how fucked do you have to be to not see how bad that is?
comments.author: Victor Ware

comments.text:
+Wout12345
There is an interesting competition between China and Japan about Africa, 
namely China builds infrastructure, and Japan, being a lesser able donor, 
sells cars. The party supports every system, even dictatorships, as long as 
it is beneficial to them, with propagating, that there is no "colonial 
remorse" or "democratic attachment" to their actions. This is hard to 
counteract in the West, since during economic turmoil, and the US largely 
dependent on Chinese goods, it is near impossible to coordinate both a 
humanitarian, and an economic effort on our part, nonetheless we should 
try, before the continent becomes an internal colony to its own elite. In 
theory, if I could persuade them, I would say, expand fair trade, so that 
goods from Africa become available to Africans as well, since it's ironic, 
that people in Côte D'Ivoire are unable to buy chocolate, whereas nouveau 
riches in Shanghai pay extra money to buy artisanal Austrian chocolate 
shipped directly from Austria.
comments.author: Akos Barati

comments.text:
+Akos Barati I don't know about China really ... What I'm hearing here from 
Western sources on their influence on Africa is just ironic on the best 
side, hypocrisy on the worst side. "Yeah yeah, we used to use and still 
exploit SE Asia for our own benefit and stuff, but now they're doing it in 
Africa!" ... that's what it sounds like to me. I for one actually support 
their actions. Our little humanitarian aid doesn't make it, their 
large-scale investments in the actual economy actually do make it. Consider 
it the lesser evil, I suppose.
comments.author: Wout12345

comments.text:
+Wout12345
In that case, I apologize. Access to educational material is largely fast, 
thanks to cheap laptops they provide to less developed areas, cyber 
infrastructure especially in Africa can grow faster, since due to huge lack 
in landlines, the continent could straight jump to cellular data 
transmission, and just recently I watched a Wikimedia clip about a native 
Peruvian tribe, who has a teacher from New York, and since the country 
never did urbanohistorical research in some distant parts, the newest 
generation is there to introduce their microregion to Wikipedia.

Global economy is a harder nut to crack, as BRICS countries, especially the 
PRC is overrepresented compared to Western donors, and unlike IMF, China 
does not further democratical changes, which in turn will only deepen the 
tribal and cultural conflicts amongst the many different nations and 
cultures in Africa.
comments.author: Akos Barati

comments.text:
+Akos Barati Sure, I agree with most of what you say, but I don't really 
see the relevance to be honest. :/ To me, how long it takes to watch videos 
like these and engage down here from Ethiopia seemed trivial to me at 
first, compared to for example how long it takes to have access to 
educational material, the global economy, ... Stereotypes and cultural 
bias, although certainly important, were not really part of my point.
comments.author: Wout12345

comments.text:
+Wout12345
 I was responding to yours, but sometimes Youtube refuses to highlight the 
original poster... I'm sure, that you are a well meaning person, I was only 
pointing out, that for most of us, who learned English, French, German, 
Spanish, Portugese, Italian, Dutch, Turkish, or Russian as a second 
language, there is a challenge to get noticed in the platforms of social 
media, since even beyond obvious hate and ignorance, there are still 
people, who master their own culture, and isolate themselves from others, 
so pronouncing and understanding names falls hard, although there should 
be, in theory no difference between two ideas.

Case in point, Ethiopia, aside for Liberia was the only country never 
colonized, and since Eritrea's departure, does not have to largely struggle 
with things we knew in the '80s. They produce one of the world's best 
coffees, and some expensive gloves, yet as John pointed out, we mostly 
regard the continent as one country. My ideal is, that progressive people 
should be able to overstep cultural boundaries, and ease the situation of 
less developed countries with being open to experiences, ideas, and 
suggestion from others, regardless, if we have problems pronouncing a name, 
and don't know right away, if our conversational partner is a he or a she.
comments.author: Akos Barati

comments.text:
+Akos Barati I don't really understand what you're trying to say, could you 
please specify what post you are responding to? :o
comments.author: Wout12345

comments.text:
I don't think, you would have to go that far, open social communities can 
only grow, wherever they are, if the participants already have an open 
mind, and don't just use the internet for spreading narrow-minded ideas 
with absolute lack of critical thinking. The second barrier, and a not less 
important one: has anyone discovered before, that when one uses a global 
language, most of the time one is only likely to read and respond to those, 
whose names are from nations of former colonizers?
comments.author: Akos Barati

comments.text:
+Kaitlyn Franco Actually, I've been told that Africa was probably worst off 
during 20th century globalization, as competition grew from growing 
economies like China, Brazil, India, ... and a whole new market became 
available from the US and Europe. I think opening up African economies to 
the world mostly meant global outsourcing of farming, which is extremely 
harmful to economies where 90% of the population works in agriculture (by 
the way, I don't know that number for sure, feel free to correct me). 
However, looking at videos like these, I definitely think African economies 
are adapting to globalization these days and are rapidly growing that way.
comments.author: Wout12345

comments.text:
+vlogbrothers Hmm, sure. I guess it's not really a great benefit for their 
society then, but probably for us. Thanks for answering.
comments.author: Wout12345

comments.text:
+Hannah Lou I'd say yes and no. It's definitely nice to hear something from 
people within the field, but then again, I think stories from people like 
John are also very valuable on another level, as he knows our culture well, 
you know, being born and raised in it. That allows him to tell the story in 
a way that we can relate to, as he can stress the differences between our 
cultures, whereas someone who lived their entire life in the developing 
world has probably only seen the West on a superficial level, like we see 
them through our media, and most likely wouldn't be able to stress the big 
differences we can relate to. Of course, this whole point only applies to 
Western viewers, but let's face it, that's the large majority of people 
watching this.
comments.author: Wout12345

comments.text:
+vlogbrothers I think globalization is one of the best things to happen to 
the world too, and if people from Ethiopia aren't reaching out and making 
friends and connections worldwide, it may affect their growth. Thoughts?
comments.author: Kaitlyn Franco

comments.text:
The issue to me is that those of us in online communities think of them as 
being broad and inclusive, when in fact they aren't. So too often online we 
don't mentally include people (even privileged people) from poor countries 
in our discussions online. This ends up making our online communities, even 
big and inclusive ones like tumblr or (I hope) nerdfighteria, deeply 
biased. -John
comments.author: vlogbrothers

comments.text:
Something else that I think is important on this front--scrolling through 
the comments here, I see some (not many) from Ethiopians, giving their 
perspective on this video, the issues raised, & other things. Western 
nerdfighters are asking questions like "what does this charity/these 
initiatives etc look to you? In reality?" They are then able to answer & 
give a different perspective. Basically, internet communities provide an 
opportunity for people to have a voice that is almost unique--even this 
excellent video was still John, a privileged white American, giving voice 
to them, rather than people making their own content & with their own 
unfiltered voices. Not knocking John at all, this is an excellent & 
important video, but I think that videos by Ethiopians on these topics 
would be even more powerful. It's much more difficult for people to 
participate and talk about this type of stuff if they don't have access to 
the right resources.
comments.author: Hannah Lou

top_comment.text:
I can see how Ethiopians would be very concerned about the "brain drain" 
where many of their educated people move out permanently.  Here in the 
Seattle area there is a rather active East African community, and you will 
find people in health care fields from several different nations here, 
wanting to come to America and stay here for the better life it offers. 
 Just off the top of my head, I've met people from Ghana, Kenya, Ethiopia, 
and Eritrea, and I'm certain I've forgotten others.  

The owner of the adult family home I reside in was born in what it now 
Eritrea, as was his wife, and they spent time in Sudan during the Eritrean 
war of independence (And they have some strong opinions of Cold War 
politics).  Their oldest daughter was born in Sudan, and their youngest was 
adopted from a brother.  I ask them questions because I'm quite curious 
about them and their lives, and they are my friends as well.  But they live 
here, now, and they are naturalized citizens (I think their sons might be 
native-born Americans, in fact), and it is Eritrea's loss and our gain 
here.  

My most recent live-in caregiver just went back to Ethiopia, but she vows 
it's only going to be for three months, since she very much wants to stay 
in the United States, because of the opportunities here.  Which gets me 
thinking how difficult things are when immigrants will work long hours for 
low pay here, and fight to stay and improve their chances at integrating.﻿
top_comment.author: Rich Wendling

comments.text:
Material progress or some social differenciation hasn´t anything to do with 
a likeable (from a western, post french revoluntion perspective) world. 
Countries like Qatar, Oman and China speak tons about the difference 
between material development and free cultures. In this sense, I do not 
like any approach that implies that, politically speaking, 'everything is 
the same'. If women are mistreated  'well, it is a cultural difference'. 
'ey they starved half their population during the 90s', 'ah, well, but 
today they have less famines', 'they prosecute homosexuals' 'well, that is 
a western particularity'. Lawyers and engineers do not tell me how much 
free press, parties and democratic quality those (Ethiopia, Somalia, 
Eritrea) countries have. Even more, lawyers could communicate through the 
internet, even support women rights initiatives, and then defend a 
government that just doesn´t care. Yes, conditions and context don´t allow 
otherwise. but moral and political choices do count, even if they are under 
pressure. In this agenda Ethiopia not only hasn´t improved, it has 
worsened. Just as wikipedia says: "Ethiopia is an "authoritarian regime", 
ranking as the 118th most democratic out of 167 countries.[92] Ethiopia has 
dropped 12 places on the list since 2006, and the latest report attributes 
the drop to the regime's crackdown on opposition activities, media and 
civil society before the 2010 parliamentary election, which the report 
argues has made Ethiopia a de facto one-party state.".

comments.text:
John it's interesting that you talk about internet access and how that 
translates into the ability of people to become active participants of the 
world. I was looking at this map the other day: 
http://www.reddit.com/r/dataisbeautiful/comments/2evjkz/i_pinged_all_devices_on_the_internet_heres_a_map/

I think if you could quantify soft power and map internet usage vs. a 
country's soft power, you would find a pretty clear correlation between the 
two. Let's face it, the internet is essentially how most of us get our 
information in this era. Since the majority of people on earth won't have 
the luxury of choosing to travel frequently, the conversations we have 
online with strangers from other countries form the basis of how we 
perceive others from different countries. The internet holds a LOT of white 
noise but I think the problem starts when some voices, which hold similar 
backgrounds and cultural references are MASSIVELY louder than others. 
Telling stories on behalf of others - or giving them a platform is useful, 
but I think it would be more useful for our cultural understanding of the 
other if online communities (particularly sites like Reddit and Tumblr that 
allow easy interaction between strangers, as opposed to Facebook which 
limits you more to your existing group of acquaintances) if voices from 
different countries were heard more frequently.

I feel like it would be extremely interest to map the effect of internet 
exposure on soft power and the perception of other people within the world!
comments.author: Angelina Li

captions.text: Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday.

So when we think of Africa, we often think
of it as one place, right? You know, it's

this poor, disease-ridden continent where
people live in thatched-roof huts and children

don't get good educations, and then there's
like a tiny wealthy elite, most of whom wear

overly decorous military uniforms, smoke cigars,
and laugh about all of the aid that they're
embezzling.
But yeah, no.

For one thing, Africa isn't just one place.
Most Canadians live closer to Venezuela than

Liberians live to Botswana. But for another,
those stereotypes are just ridiculous. I mean,

I did meet a lot of people who live in thatched-roof
huts in Ethiopia and a lot of children who

didn't have access to good schools, and corruption
remains a significant problem, BUT just as

Ethiopia's poverty rate is falling, its middle
class is rising. More and more kids go to

primary school, and the main university in
Addis Ababa which in 1950 had thirty-two students

today has more than 42,000. And when I was
in Ethiopia I got to meet a bunch of them

with Bill Gates including this young woman,
Meheret, who started an anti-domestic violence
initiative.

[Meheret:] Basically a group of volunteers
that, uh, that want to see a better community

and that want to see a better country and
a better society so we bas—so we work on
gender and race violence.

[John:] So yeah, Ethiopia has anti-domestic
violence activists and insurance agents and
web developers and nurses and etcetera.

Okay Hank, I want to give you a sense of some
of these students, like these two young women

are pre-med, and they talked a lot about the
risks and opportunities of working abroad.

[Pre-med student:] There are so many brilliant
minds going to the Western countries and,
you know, they won't come back.

[John:] The other students were future engineers
and lawyers and a couple people who weren't

sure what they wanted to do yet. You know,
like me in college.

I waited until like three minutes into the
conversation before I asked if they watched
Youtube.
[John:] Do—do you watch videos on Youtube?
[Student:] Yeah.
[John:] For fun, or for school?
[Student:] For fun and for school.

[John:] Hank, for fun AND for school?! These
people are nerdfighters if ever I have seen
one.

But this brings up an interesting problem,
which is that the internet in Ethiopia is

CRAZY SLOW. [Dial-up modem noise plays] I
mean, like, yes, that slow. That makes it

hard to watch a lot of creators, it makes
it hard to comment; it also takes forever

for Tumblr to load. And we talked about how
that makes it hard to be an active participant

in online communities. Almost all of their
social media interaction happens with people

they know in real life. To which I said, "What
is real life??"

It was also interesting to talk to them about
platforms. Like, I asked this future engineer
what what social media he uses…

[Future engineer:] Facebook not as much now.
I'm more going to Twitter now.

[John:] That's right, Hank. College students
all over the world are so over Facebook.

Also, just like I hear from a lot of American
students, these students felt a lot of tension

between, like, what they dreamt of doing and
what they'd been told they should do. Although

in their case it wasn't just about parental
wishes or future job opportunities, there
was also a kind of larger sense of responsibility.

[Future engineer:] Something is expected from
you in terms of what your country really needs
now.

[John:] And I also heard a lot of concern,
which I'm sure some nerdfighters can relate

to, that book-learning might not translate
to real-world success.

[Student:] You know, I got A+ on different
subjects. I know how to do integrations. But
how can I just express that in reality?

[John:] Hank I think we have to pause quickly
here just to note the astonishing zit on the

side of my neck. Are you sentient, zit? Do
you have a soul?

Anyway, so after meeting with these students,
I went to the library's bathroom, where there

was a bucket full of water that you had to
pour into the tank in order to make the toilet

flush because there is no running water in
the library.

Hank, there isn't just one Ethiopia. The college
library with no water is Ethiopia, but these

future engineers who will build the city's
infrastructure are also Ethiopia. These kids

are Ethiopia, and so is this doctor, and so
are these farmers, and so is this presidential

marching band. Now I know that when we see
Africa on the news or in the movies it's always

like "War! Pirates! Refugees! Disease!" But
the stories I saw in Ethiopia were far more

complicated and ultimately more compelling.
These remarkable young people have seen the

greatest drops in poverty rates and infant
mortality in their country's history, but

every year in Ethiopia, tens of thousands
of children still die of easily-preventable

diseases. And if we've learned one thing from
Global health in the last twenty years, it's

that if those kids don't die, and they don't
have to, then they can grow up and end up
studying in that library.
I'll see you on Friday.
